entry.title: A New Beginning: SAP Stammtisch Berlin on September 25th
entry.content:
Finally, it happened on September 25th: The SAP Stammtisch Berlin was back after a break of more than a year! Although we had hoped for more attendees, the small but excellent group marked an important new beginning.

The discussions were incredibly engaging and revolved around the most pressing topics in the SAP universe today. Central to our talks were the journey from the old on-premise world to the SAP Cloud and the growing use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in businesses. It became very clear how diverse the perspectives and approaches are—among both customer decision-makers and consultants. This exchange highlighted once again how essential it is to network.

For this reason, it is certain: We will continue the Stammtisch format! We hope to attract broader interest and a larger turnout next time. We plan to make the next attempt in November 2025, likely timed with the TechEd in Berlin.

Stay tuned and join us for the next Stammtisch!

-----

Am 25.09. war es endlich so weit: Nach über einem Jahr Pause fand der SAP Stammtisch Berlin wieder statt! Auch wenn wir uns über mehr Teilnehmer gefreut hätten, markierte die kleine, aber feine Runde einen wichtigen Neuanfang.

Die Gespräche waren überaus spannend und drehten sich um die aktuell brennendsten Themen im SAP Universum. Im Mittelpunkt standen der Weg von der alten On-Premise-Welt in die SAP Cloud und der zunehmende Einsatz von Künstlicher Intelligenz (KI) in Unternehmen. Es wurde sehr deutlich, wie unterschiedlich die Perspektiven und Herangehensweisen sind – sowohl bei Kunden-Verantwortlichen als auch bei Beratern. Dieser Austausch hat einmal mehr gezeigt, wie unerlässlich es ist, sich zu vernetzen.

Deshalb ist klar: Wir werden das Format des Stammtisches fortsetzen! Wir hoffen, beim nächsten Mal auf ein breiteres Interesse und eine größere Teilnahme. Den nächsten Anlauf nehmen wir voraussichtlich im November 2025 rund um die TechEd in Berlin.

Bleibt dran und nehmt am nächsten Stammtisch teil!

Vielen Dank Eric (@ezeugner) und Daniel (@danielpolzin)  für den tollen Abend und die hervorragenden Gespräche. Vielen Dank auch für die Bilder, Daniel@.

entry.title: From Insight to Impact: Measuring Business Outcomes with Data Driven Value Management
entry.content:
In my earlier blog, published in 2022, Value Management: The Key to Successful Digital Transformation, we explored why value management forms the foundation of successful transformation programs.

Since then, SAP has significantly expanded its Business Transformation Management portfolio with solutions such as SAP Signavio, LeanIX, and WalkMe. This combined focus is helping customers look beyond technology deployments — enabling them to improve business processes, strengthen enterprise architecture, drive solution adoption, and prepare their organizations for transformations, continuous improvement, and the emerging AI-driven future.

A key practice that has gained strong momentum is data-driven business value management — using real process and operational data to quantify opportunities, prioritize change, and track measurable outcomes over time.

In this follow-up, we move from theory to practice — using SAP Signavio to identify, qualify, and realize value based on real process execution data — and building the governance model that sustains value delivery long after go-live.

Why Process Data is a Game-Changer

For years, value management relied on ROI models, benchmarks, and expert opinions. While these provided direction, they often left executives asking:

“How do we know this is really true for us?”

This is where process data changes everything. By leveraging execution data from your own systems, you can see exactly how your processes run, where bottlenecks exist, and what they cost — in real time.

This shift is groundbreaking because it transforms value management from a hypothetical, static exercise into a continuous, data-driven discipline that links transformation initiatives directly to measurable business outcomes.

What Process Data Delivers

Process data — captured through SAP Signavio Process Insights and Process Intelligence — enables organizations to:

  • Gain full transparency – a clear, objective view of how processes actually perform.
  • Quantify the impact – number of cases affected, hours consumed, and cost implications.
  • Apply business context – filter by region, product, or company code to focus on where change matters most.

Instead of “best-guess” benefits, you get a fact-based foundation to align business and IT on where to act first.

 

A Phased Approach to Value Realization

 Once process data is available, we follow a structured methodology to translate insights into measurable outcomes.

0. Strategic Objectives

Align with stakeholders on what success looks like — growth, margin expansion, compliance, or efficiency — and define value drivers that will guide prioritization.

1. Value Identification

Use Signavio to uncover inefficiencies — blocked invoices, rework loops, excessive manual touchpoints — and quantify their impact to create a single version of the truth.

2. Value Qualification

Collaborate with business owners to validate findings, prioritize opportunities by business impact, and develop a high-level action plan to capture value.

3. Value Monitoring

Establish the value monitoring capabilities 

  • Configuring monitoring dashboards within SAP Signavio Process Insights and Process Intelligence to track these KPIs in near real time.
  • Setting up alerts and trend analysis so that deviations from expected benefits are visible early.
  • Embedding monitoring into BAU so that value tracking becomes part of daily operational rhythm

4. Value Governance & Realization

Measure actual outcomes, verify benefits, and feed learnings into future cycles. Governance ensures accountability and turns this into a continuous loop rather than a one-off report.

Governance: The Key to Sustained Value

True value realization is not about dashboards alone — it’s about ownership and accountability:

  • Executive Steering: Sponsors provide direction and clear roadblocks.
  • Benefit Owners: Individuals take responsibility for outcomes in their area.
  • Transparent Reporting: Progress reviews keep the organization focused on results.

Governance turns value realization into a management discipline that survives beyond project close and keeps value visible to all stakeholders.

 

Scaling Beyond Tactical Wins: Embedding Value at the Core

The journey to value realization is not just about fixing isolated problems — it’s about making value the lens through which every initiative is planned and measured.

As shown in the graphic, organizations evolve across three dimensions:

  • Tactical: Resolve immediate pain points and stabilize operations to drive functional excellence.
  • Optimization: Move into continuous improvement and functional innovation, using process insights to elevate KPIs and operational efficiency.
  • Strategic: Orchestrate cross-functional enterprise transformation where value delivery becomes a shared, organization-wide objective.

When value is at the center, it becomes the North Star for:

  • Continuous Improvement in BAU: Incremental enhancements to keep operations efficient and compliant.
  • Functional Transformations: Major initiatives like finance transformation or supply chain modernization, measured not by go-live but by benefits delivered.
  • Enterprise-Wide Programs: Cross-functional transformations delivering outcomes like margin improvement, sustainability targets, or improved customer experience.

This ensures that every dollar invested in change is tied to measurable business outcomes, creating a culture of value-centricity where progress is continuously monitored, governed, and optimized.

 

Key Takeaways

  • Data-first approach: Process data replaces assumptions with measurable facts.
  • Governance matters: Aligns teams and ensures accountability for value delivery.
  • Continuous loop: Value identification, execution, and measurement never stop.

Call to Action

If your business cases still rely on static assumptions, it’s time to modernize. SAP Signavio can provide a fact-based baseline in days and help you build a governance-backed value framework that delivers results — and sustains them.

entry.title: Re: How to get assignmentEndDate field to Variable Pay As...
entry.content: @swagatikapanda I had this requirement on a project where we used point in time as of 3/1 but the customer wanted to bring the salary from the last assignment of the year (so not necessarily 12/31, could be 11/1 if the person terminated on that date) into the summary level. There is a much easier solution to do this than what is documented in the blog. You simply need to bring over the salary from its varpayemphist table column into an ALCF (see number 3 of this blog) then copy its ID into a custom column you created for one of your sections (BusSection or IndSection). Once you have that in place, take the ID of the BusSection or IndSection custom column you created and paste it into a summary level custom column. Now you can also easily bring this salary of the last assignment of the year back to the Assignement level by create a new ALCF column (second one) and paste the ID of the summary level column into that ALCF column.

entry.title: System Audit Trail Reporting in SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
Have you ever wondered how you can view changes made to the Approval Groups and Rules, without taking numerous screenshots or manually tracking?

In this blog, we outline the steps to view, track, and download the changes made to Approval Groups and Rules in SAP Fieldglass. Read on to find out more. You can also download this information as a one-page guide.

Prerequisites

  • The relevant Users must have access to the System Audit Trail  - this access is granted through the View System Audit Trail User Role Administrative Permission
  • Approval Groups will only appear if they exist within your workflows
  • Approval Rules appear if the existing Rule Engine company configuration is enabled and Rules have been created

How to Get Started

  1. From the Admin Menu, navigate to System Tools and select System Audit Trail
  2. Select the filter information for the data that you want to retrieve, such as User, Module, Dates, Activity
  3. Click Apply Filters
  4. Check the boxes next to the data lines that you need: This action will determine what is included in the XLSX output file
  5. Click Download Activity Data
  6. An XLSX file will be ready to download:
    • The download output will include a legend in the first row with text that states *Highlight indicates change. The rest of the header rows will include columns for System Audit Trail fields.
    • The Version column will indicate a BEFORE view of the record and the AFTER view of the record (view after Edit/Remove).
    • If an entire Approval Group or Approval Rule is removed, then the output will show all the BEFORE rows with all values highlighted. No AFTER rows will appear, as it has been removed from the database.
    • If the field isn’t applicable (no Rule/Script/Variable), a blank will appear for both BEFORE and AFTER.

Next Steps

  • Download this information as a one-page guide.
  • Visit the SAP Fieldglass Help Portal for more information about the System Audit Trail.

entry.title: Optimizing SAP Analytics Cloud – Best Practices and Performance
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) offers powerful capabilities for planning, analytics, and business intelligence—all in one unified platform. But to truly unlock its potential, it's essential to follow best practices that ensure optimal performance, scalability, and maintainability. In this blog, we’ll explore some of the insights and recommendations across four key pillars of SAC:

  • Analytics & Planning Modeling: Structuring your models for flexibility, performance, and future growth.
  • Calculations: Designing efficient formulas and leveraging SAC’s calculation engine wisely.
  • Data Actions: Automating planning workflows with precision and minimal overhead.
  • Story Building: Crafting intuitive, responsive, and insightful dashboards that drive decision-making.

Performance Considerations

Performance in SAC isn’t a post-implementation concern—it must be a core priority from the very beginning of your project. Striking the right balance between rich functionality and responsive performance is essential. While functional requirements drive business value, they must be matched by a system that performs reliably and efficiently. Performance optimization touches every layer of your SAC solution: from backend data architecture and model design to story layout, user concurrency, and even device and network configurations.

Model Design

  • Model Scope: Clearly define the model’s scope, type (planning or analytics), required metrics, and data granularity based on business objectives. This clarity prevents over engineering and ensures alignment with user needs.
  • Reusability: Build modular models that can be reused across multiple stories and planning scenarios. Reusability reduces duplication, simplifies maintenance, and accelerates development cycles.
  • Lean Model Structure: Key performance drivers include the number of measures, dimensions, hierarchies, and members per dimension. Reducing unnecessary dimensions and avoiding overly complex hierarchies directly improves query performance and system responsiveness. Focus on dimensions that are essential for data collection. Attributes such as geographic area or gender can often be derived rather than modeled as standalone dimensions. Evaluate whether static dimensions can be converted into attributes, and consider splitting large models into smaller, purpose-driven ones. Simpler models are easier to maintain, faster to calculate, and more memory efficient. Avoid adding dimensions or calculations unless they deliver clear business value.
  • Understanding Model Types: From a performance perspective, Analytic Models connected to live data sources place minimal demand on SAC infrastructure, as most of the processing load is handled by the source system itself. In contrast, Analytic Models using acquired data rely on the embedded HANA database, primarily for read operations. While this does introduce some system load, it tends to be moderate and more CPU-intensive than memory-intensive. Planning Models with acquired data, however, offer richer functionality but come with higher resource requirements—impacting both CPU and memory. Their performance is heavily influenced by model design factors such as the number of exception aggregations, the complexity and volume of dimensions, and the breadth of the user’s security context during data entry operations.
  • Additional performance-critical factors include the number of concurrent users, the volume and structure of the data, and the frequency and complexity of scheduled jobs or data actions also play a significant role in determining system responsiveness and scalability.
  • Use Measure Based Model: When designing models in SAC, opting for a Measure-Based Model is highly recommended due to its significant advantages in performance, calculation flexibility, and overall modeling efficiency.
    • Enhanced Performance & Scalability: Measure-based models are optimized for faster processing and reduced complexity, especially in large-scale planning scenarios.
    • Flexible Structure: These models support both accounts and measures, with the account dimension now optional giving you greater design freedom.
    • Reusable Calculations: You can define base measure calculations that simplify logic reuse across stories and planning workflows.
    • Advanced Aggregation: Measures can be aggregated more efficiently, improving responsiveness and reducing load times.
    • Expanded Data Type Support: Measure-based models accommodate a wider range of data types, enhancing versatility.
    • Multi-Currency Planning: With base currency measures, currency conversion becomes seamless, enabling planning across multiple currencies with ease.

Dimension Design

  • Leverage Public Dimensions: Use the Public Dimension feature to manage master data independently, allowing for centralized updates and reuse across models. Avoid importing all source system tables—focus only on dimensions relevant to data entry and planning.
  • Dimension hierarchies and members: Deep hierarchies can be resource intensive. Limit the number of levels to reduce complexity and improve query performance. Keep the number of members in each dimension—including the Account dimension—lean. Import only valid members and apply filters to exclude irrelevant data.
  • Date Dimension: Use SAC’s standard date dimension with SAP-managed hierarchies (Year–Quarter–Month–Day) to minimize performance impact.

Planning Area

  • The planning area defines the specific slice of data within a model that end users can interact with—whether through stories or data actions. When users plan on a public version in a story, SAC automatically creates an implicit private version behind the scenes. This version isn’t visible to the user but introduces system overhead, especially in models with large datasets or when multiple users are editing simultaneously. To mitigate this, it’s crucial to explicitly define the planning area in the model settings and enable it within the story. Doing so significantly reduces resource consumption during public version edits. Key recommendations include:
  • Configure a Targeted Planning Area: Set a focused scope based on business needs, using data access control, data locking, or both to restrict editable data.
  • Avoid Full Dataset Scope: Limiting the planning area prevents unnecessary data loading and improves performance.
  • Use Data Access Control(DAC): Define which users can write to specific dimensions—such as company codes or profit centers—to ensure secure and relevant access.
  • Apply Data Locking: Protect actuals from being overwritten by locking them from edits.
  • Enable Dynamic Planning Area: Set “Auto-generate based on table context” as the default. This allows the planning area to adjust automatically based on filters, story context, or table layout—ensuring users only load what they need.

SAC Planning Best Practices

  • Use Unbooked Data selectively: Enable unbooked data only when necessary—typically for planning use cases. Since it triggers resource-intensive backend queries, it's best disabled for reporting scenarios to preserve performance.
  • Implement DAC: Always activate DAC on relevant dimensions to enforce row-level security. This ensures users only see and interact with data within their authorized scope, reducing system load during public version edits. DAC should be configured during the model design phase. DAC can be turned ON in the Model Dimension through the Read/Write Property or the Data Access Filter in Role by turning the Model Data Privacy ON so DAC can be combined with role-based restrictions. Use DAC primarily on planning-relevant dimensions (E.g. Cost Center, Profit Center, Region), not on all dimensions.
  • Complement with Data Locks :  While DAC governs who can read/write data, Data Locks control when data can be modified (e.g., freezing approved budgets). This combination enhances performance, especially in multi-user environments. Minimize driving dimensions when using data locking to reduce overhead.
  • Define Validation Rules: Ensure users can only edit valid combinations of dimension members. This is particularly important for models with large dimension tables and helps maintain data integrity while improving performance.
  • Limit Private versions: Excessive private versions—especially when multiple users are editing simultaneously—can strain system resources. Regularly clean up unused private versions to maintain system efficiency.
  • Manage Date Granularity: For models with day-level granularity, consider isolating them into separate models. Use cross-model copy data actions to transfer aggregated data, reducing complexity and improving performance.
  • Use Modeler option ‘Optimize Story Building Performance’ : This prevents the automatic refresh of data during story design. When importing or writing back datasets, use filters or pre-aggregation to reduce data volume

Calculations/Data Actions

  • Prioritize Model-Level Formulas: Define calculations within the modeler rather than at the story level to reduce query load and improve responsiveness.
  • Offload Complex: Logic to Data Actions Use data actions for advanced formulas and heavy computations instead of embedding them directly in stories.
  • Restrict Execution Scope: Use the MEMBERSET statement to narrow the scope of data actions. A tightly defined scope minimizes processing time and resource usage.
  • Limit Iteration Range: Keep calculation loops (IF, FOREACH) as focused as possible. Broad iteration across dimensions can degrade performance.
  • Aggregate at the Highest Logical Level: Design calculations to occur at the most aggregated node feasible to reduce data volume and complexity.
  • Avoid Copying Calculated Accounts: Copying calculated accounts or non-standard aggregations is resource intensive. Prefer copying raw fact data when possible.
  • Configure Advanced Formulas Thoughtfully: All steps in advanced formulas execute sequentially and materialize in the model. Use variable members to streamline logic and avoid unnecessary commits.
  • Minimize Query Calls: Reduce the number of DATA() and RESULTLOOKUP() statements—each call triggers a backend query.
  • Restricted Measures Over Exception Aggregations: Exception aggregations (e.g., MIN, MAX, AVERAGE across hierarchies) are computationally expensive. Use restricted measures and advanced formulas when possible.
  • Simplify Formula Structures: Avoid breaking formulas into too many sub-steps, which increases processing overhead.
  • Recompile After Model Changes:  If performance drops after model updates, re-save the advanced formula or data action to trigger recompilation and optimization.
  • Centralize Execution for Large Volumes:  Run data actions centrally via an admin user when handling large datasets. For decentralized execution, ensure scope is tightly defined.
  • Trigger Actions Judiciously:  Avoid frequent or unnecessary data action runs. Execute only when required to conserve resources.
  • Monitor Execution Time:  Use the Data Action Monitor to track duration and identify slow-running actions.
  • Use Job Monitor for Diagnostics: Regularly review run history and step-level details to pinpoint bottlenecks and optimize performance.
  • Simplify IF Statements: Reduce reliance on IF statements by using logical operators like AND or applying filters. Each IF creates a subquery, so use sparingly.
  • Leverage Predictive Planning: Use predictive features to generate accurate forecasts based on historical data, accelerating planning cycles and improving decision-making.

Backend HANA/BW considerations

HANA modelling

  • Optimize HANA Views by following guidelines for modelling and performance tuning.
  • Perform Calculations Post-Aggregation: Whenever possible, structure views to calculate after aggregation to reduce data volume and improve speed.
  • Join on Indexed Columns: Use keys or indexed columns for joins instead of calculated fields to enhance query performance.
  • Push Logic to HANA: Keep calculations and logic within HANA to leverage pushdown capabilities and minimize SAC-side processing.
  • Blend in HANA, Not SAC: Perform data linking and blending operations in HANA to reduce complexity and improve responsiveness.
  • Apply Filters Early: Early filtering reduces data load and improves query execution time.
  • Hide Unused Dimensions in SAC: Remove unnecessary metadata from SAC models to streamline performance and reduce clutter.

BW modelling

  • Design Efficient Queries: Limit the number of dimensions and hide unnecessary key figures to reduce query payload and improve responsiveness.
  • Use BW Variables Over SAC Filters: BW variables are processed server-side and offer better performance than applying filters within SAC stories.
  • Define Restricted Key Figures: in BW Avoid creating restricted key figures in SAC remote models. Instead, configure them directly in BW for optimized execution.
  • Minimize Cascading Page Filters: Page-level filters that trigger cascading effects across widgets can slow down performance. Use them sparingly and strategically.
  • Enable Query Merge: Activate query merge to consolidate backend calls, reducing latency and improving load times.
  • Enable HTTP/2 Protocol: Improves data transfer efficiency between SAC and BW, especially for large datasets.
  • Increase Parallel Sessions: Configure BW data sources to support more parallel sessions, enhancing concurrency and user experience.
  • Apply BI Authorizations for Data Security: Use BW’s built-in data-level security to control access and ensure users only retrieve data relevant to their roles.

Story Building Recommendations

Story Structure & Layout

  • Use Optimized or Unified Story Experience: Adopt the latest story building interface for enhanced performance, flexibility, and design capabilities.
  • Leverage Composites as Reusable Widgets: Composites are stored as SAC artifacts and can be reused across stories. They support both canvas and responsive layouts and allow story-level features like filters and bookmarks to apply seamlessly. Benefits include faster story creation, reduced maintenance, standardized design, and support for parallel development.
  • Use Responsive Layouts: Responsive pages automatically adjust to screen size and load faster. Unified stories offer advanced responsive rule configurations for precise control.

Content Design & Performance Optimization

  • Request Only What’s Needed: Break down information into manageable layers. Use summary or landing pages with hyperlinks to detailed views.
  • Minimize Page Count and Widget Load: Reduce the number of pages and limit data-heavy widgets per page to improve load times and user experience.
  • Optimize Charts and Tables:
    • Avoid charts with more than 500 data points.
    • Limit the number of charts per page to reduce backend requests.
    • Split large tables into smaller ones with fewer KPIs or measures.
    • Limit the number of cells and descriptive columns for readability.
    • Avoid excessive formatting rules and in-cell charts/calculations.
  • Use Lightweight Visuals:  Replace large image files with lightweight SVGs to reduce rendering time.

Filtering & Data Handling:

  • Implement Filters Strategically: Apply filters at the document level rather than creating generic views. Use page filters instead of individual chart filters. Avoid loading all data and filtering afterward.
  • Limit Hierarchy Depth: in Filters Deep hierarchies can slow down performance—use only necessary levels.
  • Minimize Data Blending: Sources Keep the number of blended data sources low to reduce complexity and improve responsiveness.
  • Pause Data Refresh During Design: Use the “Pause Data Refresh” option to optimize story loading while building.

Security & Access Control

  • Test With User Roles: Validate story performance using roles with end user authorizations—not just the admin role—to simulate real-world usage.
  • Apply Data Access Control (DAC): Ensure users only see data relevant to their role. For example, use filters for company code and profit center rather than displaying all dimensions.

Planning-Specific Tips

  • Use Fluid Data Entry Mode: This default mode offers better performance and interactivity. Avoid Single Data Entry mode, which is slower.
  • Enable Planning Only Where Needed: Activate planning features on tables only when required. Disable planning in the builder panel if not used.

Latest Performance Improvements

  • New Table Build Experience:  Optimized Stories – Edit Mode Enhancements.
    • Blended Tables: Initial page loading is faster.
    • Calculations: Automatically retained when tables are copied.
    • Improved Filtering & Sorting: More efficient workflows and reduced query errors.
    • Ghost Table: Instant layout preview before data loads
  • Story Design Optimization:
    • Performance recommendations in Edit Mode available for story designers in the optimized story experience.
    • Available for widget, page, and stories levels.
  • Preload pages
    • It can be enabled in edit mode under Data Refresh->Loading Optimization Settings-> Preload Pages.
    • Preloading will initialize parts of the next and previous page, so switching to these pages will now be faster.

If performance issues persist despite optimization efforts, SAC offers a suite of diagnostic tools to help pinpoint the root cause. These tools provide visibility into query execution, data action performance, and story load behavior. For detailed guidance on using these diagnostics, refer to the official SAP Help documentation or reach out to SAP Support for expert help.

entry.title: Archive SAC Change Docs into Datasphere
entry.content:
Using SAC data change documents, you can track (audit) the data changes made to any planning model. SAP Analytics Cloud logs all changes to the transaction data of that model when users publish data from private versions to public versions.

Note that a data change log has up to 2^31 (i.e., 2,147,384,648, or ~2 billion) records. When the data change log reaches its size limit, publishing data will fail, and you will see the following message:

Publish cannot be performed because the data audit table has reached the maximum number of rows.

To avoid this issue, consider periodically downloading log entries as a backup before deleting them.

This document shows a design to back up SAC audit logs into Datasphere. Using Datasphere dataflow to back up change documents from the SAC Data Export Service via a Cloud Data Integration adapter-based connection, it can back up and preserve the SAC audit log history, which is necessary for regular housekeeping in SAC due to storage capacity limits.

 

DES: data export service

CDI: cloud data integration

 

Note: In SAC seamless planning or in BDC, the SAC model definition and calculation logic remain within SAC, while the persistence for planning data and change documents are stored in SAP Datasphere, so that both systems are closely linked - without the effort of manual data transfers. Therefore, the solution might not be necessary if the SAC change documents are already stored in Datasphere.

 

The following steps outline the implementation of the solution.

In SAC, System – Administration – App Integration, create an OAuth client with Access to the Data Export Service.

 

 

In SAC, keep the OAuth Client URLs for later configuration of the connection in Datasphere.

 

 

In SAC, copy the OAuth Client ID and Client Secret for later configuration of the connection in Datasphere.

 

In Datasphere, in a space, create a Cloud Data Integration connection pointing to the SAC Data Export Service. The URL is in the format of

https://<your domain>/api/v1/dataexport/administration

 

In the connections management screen, validate the connection, and make sure the Data Flows feature is now enabled. It shall give the following message after validation on the connection.

Connection “SAC DES Change Docs” is valid. – Data flows are enabled. – Replication flows are not supported. – Remote tables are enabled.

 

In SAC, open the model with the Audit Data flag switched on, and note down the model ID in the rear part of the URL. For instance:

https://<your domain name>/sap/fpa/ui/app.html?sap-ui-theme=sap_belize#/modeler&/m/model/C4003n1icbi0loo9lvgv7t4pu41

 

In Datasphere, Data Builder- Create a Data Flow to load SAC audit logs into a target table.

  1. Use the model id to find the SAC source in the connection for the source node in the data flow.
  2. To make the daily backup more efficient, an exemplary expression implemented in the projection node can be: "Audit_Time" >= ADD_DAYS(NOW(), -1).
  3. To preserve the audit logs history that might be regularly cleaned in SAC, use Append mode on the target table for UPSERT.

 

 

 

In Datasphere, execute the data flow to load SAC audit logs and verify that the data is now present in Datasphere. Then, delete the audit logs in SAC, execute the data flow again to check that the audit logs history has been preserved after cleansing audit logs in SAC.

 

Last but not least, you may also develop an analytic model on top of the audit logs history table in Datasphere for analytics and build a report or visualization in SAC.

Note:

CDI connection type also supports the remote table as well as the data flow feature.

Remote table can use the following replication types, but none of those replications can well preserve the change document history.

  • Replication (snapshot)
  • Replication (real-time)

entry.title: Unlocking the SAP Foundation: From Company Codes to Business Partners 🔑
entry.content:
The Ultimate SAP S/4HANA Master Data Guide

Introduction

Welcome to your all-in-one guide to Master Data in SAP S/4HANA. This document is designed for everyone, from end-users performing daily tasks and dummies just starting their SAP journey, to key users responsible for training and testing, and consultants who design and configure the system.

Master data is the bedrock of your organization's processes within SAP. It represents the core business objects that are shared and used across different departments and modules. Think of it as the "nouns" of your business: your customers, your products, your suppliers, and your assets. Keeping this data clean, accurate, and consistent is the single most important factor for a successful SAP implementation.

This guide transforms the principles from the provided R/3 and ECC documents into a modern, cohesive S/4HANA context. We will focus on standard end-to-end business processes, using SAP Fiori applications as the primary interface, while also providing SAP GUI transactions for reference.

Chapter 1: The Foundation - Organizational and Core Data

Before we can create products or transact with partners, we must establish the structure of our enterprise in the system and understand the core data principles.

1.1 Company and Plant Settings for Material Management

Certain foundational settings control how materials and inventory are managed at the highest levels.

Concept: Authorizing Prior Period Postings

In accounting, periods (usually corresponding to months) are closed to finalize financial statements. However, sometimes a goods movement that occurred in a previous, now-closed period needs to be recorded. SAP allows you, on a company-code-by-company-code basis, to authorize posting to the previous period.

This is a critical setting managed by finance and logistics teams. If authorized, when the current period is, for example, October, the system can still accept postings for September.

How-To: Manage Settings for Material Management

This is a configuration activity typically performed by a consultant.

  • SAP GUI Transaction: OMSY
  • SPRO Path: Logistics - General > Material Master > Basic Settings > Maintain Company Codes for Materials Management

Instructions:

  1. In the OMSY transaction, you will see a list of all company codes set up in the system.
  2. Find the company code you wish to manage (e.g., 1010).
  3. Ensure the correct current fiscal year and period are displayed.
  4. Key Field: Check the box "Allow Posting to Previous Period" (column ABP) to enable this functionality. Uncheck it to disallow it.
  5. Save your changes.

Real-World Example:

A shipment of raw materials was delivered and used on September 30th, but the paperwork was delayed and only reached the warehouse clerk on October 2nd. The current posting period is October. Because the ABP flag is set for the company code, the clerk can enter the goods receipt with a posting date of September 30th, ensuring inventory and financial records are accurate for the month in which the activity occurred.

1.2 The Business Partner (BP) Approach

In SAP S/4HANA, the classic customer (XD01) and vendor (XK01) master records are obsolete. They have been replaced by a single, unified object: the Business Partner (BP).

Concept: The Business Partner

A Business Partner can be a person, an organization, or a group. This single BP record holds general information like name, address, and bank details. Then, specific roles are assigned to the BP to determine its function in business processes.

  • General Role: Holds the basic data.
  • Customer Role (e.g., FLCU01): Contains sales-area-specific data (sales org, distribution channel, division) needed for the Sales & Distribution (SD) module.
  • Supplier Role (e.g., FLVN01): Contains purchasing-organization-specific data needed for the Materials Management (MM) module.

This approach eliminates data redundancy and provides a 360-degree view of your partners. A single company can be both a customer and a supplier, managed through one BP number with two different roles.

How-To: Create a Business Partner

  • SAP Fiori App: Manage Business Partner Master Data
  • SAP GUI Transaction: BP

Instructions (using Fiori):

  1. Open the Manage Business Partner Master Data app.
  2. Click Create and choose the type (e.g., Organization).
  3. A BP number will be assigned internally.
  4. In the "General" section, fill in the partner's name, address, and communication details.
  5. Click Add Role and select the required role, for example, FLCU01 - Customer.
  6. New tabs will appear (e.g., "Sales and Distribution"). Click on this tab.
  7. Click Add to create a new Sales Area record. Enter the Sales Organization, Distribution Channel, and Division.
  8. Fill in the required sales data, such as Shipping Conditions, Payment Terms, and the link to the company code for financial postings.
  9. To add a supplier role, simply repeat step 5 with FLVN01 - Supplier and fill in the "Purchasing" data.
  10. Save the Business Partner.

Chapter 2: The Material Master - Heart of Logistics

The Material Master is the central source of information for a product. It is used by all logistics modules (MM, SD, PP, EWM, QM, etc.) and its data determines how a material is purchased, stored, sold, produced, and costed.

2.1 Configuring the User Experience: Screen Sequences

Different users need to see different information about a material. A quality inspector cares about inspection data, while a salesperson cares about sales texts and pricing. SAP allows you to control which data screens appear, and in what order, for different users and material types.

Concept: Screen Sequences

A screen sequence is a collection of data screens (called "Views" in the Material Master, like "Basic Data", "Sales Org. Data", "Plant Data/Storage") arranged in a specific order. You can assign a screen sequence based on a combination of:

  • Transaction: Is the user creating (MM01), changing (MM02), or displaying (MM03)?
  • User: You can assign specific screen sequences to user groups.
  • Material Type: Finished goods will have different views than raw materials.
  • Industry Sector: The industry can determine default fields and views.

The system checks these assignments with a priority (1 being the highest). For example, a specific assignment for a user/material type combination will override a general assignment for just the material type111111111.

How-To: Assign Screen Sequences

This is a customizing task performed by a consultant to tailor the user interface.

  • SAP GUI Transaction: OMT3E 2222
  • SPRO Path: Logistics - General > Material Master > Configuring the Material Master > Assign Screen Sequences to User/Material Type/Transaction/Industry Sector 3

Instructions:

  1. Execute the transaction OMT3E.
  2. The main view shows the assignments of screen sequences to various combinations. The standard sequence is typically

21 (Industry - tabbed view)4444.

  1. To create a new, user-specific experience, you first need to group users or material types into a Screen Reference.
    • For example, you can assign users

DUPOND, DURAND, and DUPUIS to the same screen reference group, GR5. This is done in the sub-dialogs within the transaction.

  1. Click New Entries.
  2. Enter your new combination. For the example above, you would enter:
    • Tr... (Transaction Group): 01 (Create/Change)
    • User... (User Screen Reference): GR
    • MT... (Material Type Screen Reference): * (All)
    • Ind... (Industry Screen Reference): * (All)
    • Scr... (Screen Sequence): ZY (Your custom sequence) 6
  3. Save the entry.

Real-World Example:

A company wants its Quality Management team to only see QM-relevant data when they look at a material.

  1. A consultant creates a user screen reference QM and assigns all QM user IDs to it.
  2. The consultant creates a new screen sequence ZQM that only contains the "Quality Management" view.
  3. Using OMT3E, the consultant assigns screen sequence ZQM to the user reference QM for all transactions and material types.
  4. Now, when a QM user opens any material, they will immediately see the Quality Management view and won't be cluttered by sales, purchasing, or MRP screens.

2.2 Controlling Material Usability: Material Status

You can block or "freeze" a material from being used in certain business processes. This is controlled by the Material Status.

Concept: Freezing Material Data Fields

When a material is being phased out or is under review, you might want to prevent users from changing critical data fields like the base unit of measure or the material group. The system can be configured to "freeze" or lock specific fields when a material is created, preventing any subsequent changes.

This functionality ensures data integrity for established materials.

How-To: Define Fields Affected by Freeze

This is a configuration activity.

  • SAP GUI Transaction: OMSFIX 7
  • SPRO Path: Logistics - General > Material Master > Field Selection > Define Fields Affected by Material Master Freeze 8

Instructions:

  1. Execute transaction OMSFIX.
  2. The screen lists tables and field names corresponding to the Material Master (e.g., MARA-MEINS for Base Unit of Measure).
  3. Check the box next to any field you want to be locked after the material is first created.
  4. Save your configuration.

Note: This is a global setting. Once a field is marked here, it will be unchangeable for all materials after creation. Use this with caution. You must have defined which fields are significant for blocking in customizing9.

2.3 Batch Management

For materials requiring strict traceability, such as pharmaceuticals, food products, or paints, Batch Management is essential.

Concept: Batch Management

A "batch" is a specific quantity of a material that was produced or procured together and shares the same properties. Batch management allows you to:

  • Track products from raw material receipt to finished good delivery.
  • Manage materials with a limited shelf life.
  • Handle product recalls efficiently by isolating specific batches.

SAP can assign batch numbers internally (system generates a number automatically) or externally (user enters a number, e.g., from a supplier's document).

How-To: Activate Internal Batch Number Assignment

This functionality automates batch number creation, saving time and preventing manual entry errors10101010.

  • SAP GUI Transaction: OMCZ 11
  • SPRO Path: Logistics - General > Batch Management > Batch Number Assignment > Activate Internal Batch Number Assignment 12

Configuration Steps:

  1. Step 1: Activate at Client Level
    • Execute transaction OMCZ or navigate the SPRO path.
    • You will see two main activities. Select the first one: "Activate Batch Number Assignment"13.
    • On the next screen, select the "Active" radio button to enable internal assignment for the entire system14.
    • Save.
  2. Step 2: Activate for Goods Movements at Plant Level
    • Go back to the initial

OMCZ screen and select the second activity: "Internal batch number assignment for assigned goods receipt"15.

    • This screen lists all the plants in your system.
    • Find the plant(s) where you want automatic batch creation during goods receipt (e.g., for purchase orders or production orders).
    • Check the box in the column "N°Lot automatic for EM" for each desired plant16.
    • Save your changes17.

Execution in Practice:

Once configured, you must also set the "Batch Management" indicator in the "Purchasing" or "Work Scheduling" view of the material master for the relevant plant. When a user then posts a goods receipt for that material in that plant (e.g., using the Fiori app "Post Goods Receipt for Purchase Order" or Tx MIGO), the system will automatically create and assign a new batch number.

2.4 Handling and Storage Properties

How a material is physically handled and stored is crucial for warehouse and logistics operations. These properties are defined in the material master.

Concept: Packing Instructions & Handling Unit Management

  • Packing Instruction (formerly Container Requirement): This is a key that defines the type of container or packaging a material should be stored in and shipped with181818. For example, a material might require a "LARGE-BOX" or a "PALLET". This is managed in the "Plant Data / Storage 1" view of the material master19.
  • Handling Unit (HU) Management: A Handling Unit is a physical unit of a material and its packaging (e.g., 24 pieces in a box, 48 boxes on a pallet). Some storage locations can be designated as "HU-managed," meaning that all inventory movements must be executed by specifying an HU number. This provides precise tracking of physical stock.

How-To: Define Packing Instructions

This is a simple configuration table defining the possible packing types.

  • SPRO Path: Logistics - General > Material Master > Settings for Key Fields > Define Packing Instructions 20

Instructions:

  1. Navigate to the SPRO path.
  2. Click New Entries.
  3. Enter a short code for the instruction (e.g.,

B12) and a description (e.g., Cardboard Box A12)21.

  1. Save your entries. These values will now be available for selection in the material master.

How-To: Set HU Management for Storage Locations

This setting activates mandatory HU usage for a specific storage location.

  • SPRO Path: Logistics - General > Handling Unit Management > Basics > Materials Management > Inventory Management > HU Requirement for Storage Locations and Default Values for Deliveries 22

Instructions:

  1. Navigate to the IMG path. The system will show a list of plants.
  2. Select a plant and double-click on "Storage Location" in the dialog structure on the left.
  3. For the desired storage location, check the box "HU Oblig." (Handling Unit Management mandatory).
  4. Important Prerequisite: You can only activate this for storage locations that have no stock23.
  5. When this flag is set, you cannot post standard goods movements. Instead, the system will create a delivery document to handle the HU movement24.
  6. You can also set default Partner information (e.g., shipping point, customer) to be used when these deliveries are automatically created.
  7. Save your settings.

2.5 Using the Classification System

The SAP Classification system allows you to add custom characteristics to your master data objects, like Materials or Batches, enabling you to search for them using very specific criteria.

Concept: Classes and Characteristics

  • Characteristics: These are the fields you want to use for searching (e.g., "Color," "Diameter," "Purity %").
  • Class: A class is a container for characteristics that are logically grouped together. You assign an object (like a material) to a class to give it those characteristics.

For example, you could create a class STEEL_BARS with characteristics like DIAMETER, LENGTH, and ALLOY_GRADE. You can then assign all your steel bar materials to this class and specify the values for each.

How-To: Find Objects in Classes

The CL30N transaction is a powerful tool used to find objects based on their characteristic values. It's especially useful for finding batches with specific properties.

  • SAP GUI Transaction: CL30N 25

Instructions:

  1. Launch transaction CL30N.
  2. Enter the Class you want to search in (e.g., PF_COLLERET).
  3. Enter the

Class Type (e.g., 022 or 023 for Batches)26.

  1. Press Enter.
  2. The system will display all the characteristics assigned to that class.
  3. Enter the values you want to search for. For example, for a characteristic Commentaire 1, you could enter TOUTES LES BARRES* (find all that start with "TOUTES LES BARRES").
  4. Click the Find in initial class button or press F8.
  5. The system will return a list of all objects (in this case, materials/batches) that match your search criteria.

2.6 Logistics Information System (LIS) Settings

The LIS is a reporting and analytics tool. To ensure data is captured correctly for analysis, certain parameters, like variance grids, must be maintained.

Concept: Variance Grids

For supplier evaluation and logistics controlling, you often need to analyze how well suppliers meet their promised delivery dates and quantities. The LIS uses a "grid" to categorize these variances. You can define the boundaries of this grid.

  • Quantity Variance: The grid analyzes the percentage difference between the quantity ordered and the quantity delivered .
  • Delivery Date Variance: The grid analyzes the difference in days between the planned and actual delivery date .

You can define up to four interval boundaries, which creates five "classes" or categories for reporting27272727.

How-To: Maintain Variance Grids

This is a configuration task.

  • SPRO Path (Quantity): Logistics - General > Logistics Information System (LIS) > Logistics Data Warehouse > Updating > Updating Control > Settings: Purchasing > Change Quantity Reliability Grid 28
  • SPRO Path (Date): Logistics - General > Logistics Information System (LIS) > Logistics Data Warehouse > Updating > Updating Control > Settings: Purchasing > Change On-Time Delivery Performance Grid 29

Instructions:

  1. Navigate to the relevant path. The grid is determined per Purchasing Organization30303030.
  2. Select your Purchasing Organization and click Continue.
  3. You will see fields for Interval 1 to Interval 4.
  4. Enter the boundary values.
    • Example (Quantity %): Interval 1: 5, Interval 2: 10, Interval 3: 20, Interval 4: 50. This creates five buckets for reporting: 0-5% variance, 5-10%, 10-20%, 20-50%, and >50%.
    • Example (Date in Days): Interval 1: 1, Interval 2: 3, Interval 3: 7, Interval 4: 14. This creates buckets for deliveries that are 1 day late, 2-3 days late, 4-7 days late, etc.
  5. Save your configuration. This data is then used in standard LIS analysis reports.

SAP S/4HANA Master Data Test Plan

Introduction

This test plan provides a structured approach for end-users, key users, and consultants to validate the master data configurations and processes outlined in the guide. The goal is to ensure data is created correctly, system behavior matches the configured design, and end-to-end processes run smoothly.

Each test case includes an objective, prerequisites, step-by-step instructions for different roles (Consultant for configuration checks, Key/End User for execution), and expected results.

Section 1: Core and Organizational Data

Test Case OD-001: Validate Posting to Previous Period

  • Objective: To verify that the system correctly allows or blocks material postings to a closed period based on the OMSY configuration.
  • Prerequisites:
    • Access to transaction OMSY (Consultant).
    • Access to the Fiori app "Post Goods Receipt for Purchase Order" or Tx MIGO (User).
    • A purchase order for a material.
    • The current posting period is known (e.g., Period 10). The previous period (e.g., Period 9) is closed for normal postings.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Configuration Check (Consultant): In Tx OMSY, for the relevant Company Code, check the box "Allow Posting to Previous Period". Save.
    2. Execution - Scenario A (User): Launch the "Post Goods Receipt" app. Enter the purchase order number. Set the Document Date and Posting Date to a date in the previous period (Period 9). Post the goods receipt.
    3. Expected Result A: The goods receipt posts successfully with a material document number.
    4. Configuration Change (Consultant): In Tx OMSY, for the same Company Code, uncheck the box "Allow Posting to Previous Period". Save.
    5. Execution - Scenario B (User): Attempt to post another goods receipt for the same PO with the posting date in the previous period.
    6. Expected Result B: The system issues an error message stating "Posting only possible in periods [current] and [previous] in company code XXXX" or a similar message indicating the period is closed. The document does not post.
  • Pass/Fail: ____________

Section 2: Business Partner

Test Case BP-001: Create a single BP as both Customer and Supplier

  • Objective: To validate the S/4HANA Business Partner concept by creating one BP entity that can be used in both sales and purchasing processes.
  • Prerequisites:
    • Relevant Sales Area (Sales Org, Dist. Channel, Division) and Purchasing Organization exist.
    • Access to the Fiori app "Manage Business Partner Master Data".
  • Test Steps:
    1. Execution - Part 1 (User): Launch the "Manage Business Partner Master Data" app. Create a new Organization.
    2. Fill in the general data (Name, Address, etc.). Save the BP. Note the BP number.
    3. Add the Customer role (FLCU01). Go to the "Sales and Distribution" tab and create a record for your Sales Area. Fill in key fields like Shipping Conditions and Payment Terms. Save.
    4. Add the Supplier role (FLVN01). Go to the "Purchasing" tab and create a record for your Purchasing Organization. Fill in key fields like Order Currency and Payment Terms. Save.
    5. Validation - SD (User): Launch the "Create Sales Order" app (Tx VA01). Enter the BP number in the "Sold-To Party" field.
    6. Expected Result 1: The system successfully finds and accepts the BP as a customer.
    7. Validation - MM (User): Launch the "Create Purchase Order" app (Tx ME21N). Enter the BP number in the "Supplier" field.
    8. Expected Result 2: The system successfully finds and accepts the BP as a supplier.
  • Pass/Fail: ____________

Section 3: Material Master

Test Case MM-MD-001: Verify Custom Screen Sequence Assignment

  • Objective: To test the functionality configured in OMT3E, ensuring a specific group of users sees a tailored set of screens when creating a material of a specific type.
  • Prerequisites:
    • A custom screen sequence ZY has been created.
    • A user screen reference group GR has been created and your user ID is assigned to it.
    • A custom material type ZFIN (Finished Good) exists.
    • OMT3E has been configured to assign screen sequence ZY when user group GR creates a material of type ZFIN.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Execution (User): Launch the "Create Material" app (Tx MM01).
    2. Enter the Material Type ZFIN. Select any Industry Sector.
    3. Proceed to the "Select View(s)" screen.
    4. Expected Result: The list of available views and the order in which they appear on the subsequent screens should exactly match the definition of screen sequence ZY. Views not included in ZY should not be present.
  • Pass/Fail: ____________

Test Case MM-MD-002: Test Material Field Freeze

  • Objective: To verify that a field configured in OMSFIX (e.g., Base Unit of Measure) is editable during material creation but locked during change.
  • Prerequisites:
    • OMSFIX has been configured to lock the field MARA-MEINS (Base Unit of Measure).
  • Test Steps:
    1. Execution - Create (User): Launch the "Create Material" app (Tx MM01). Create a new material of any type.
    2. In the "Basic Data 1" view, observe the "Base Unit of Measure" field.
    3. Expected Result 1: The field is open for input. Enter a value (e.g., PC for piece) and save the material.
    4. Execution - Change (User): Launch the "Change Material" app (Tx MM02). Enter the material number you just created.
    5. Go to the "Basic Data 1" view and attempt to change the "Base Unit of Measure".
    6. Expected Result 2: The field is greyed out and cannot be changed.
  • Pass/Fail: ____________

Test Case MM-MD-003: Validate Internal Batch Number Assignment

  • Objective: To test the end-to-end process of automatic batch number creation during a goods receipt for a batch-managed material.
  • Prerequisites:
    • Internal batch assignment is active in OMCZ.
    • A material has been created with the "Batch management" indicator set for the relevant plant.
    • A purchase order has been created for this material and plant.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Execution (User): Launch the "Post Goods Receipt for Purchase Order" Fiori app (Tx MIGO).
    2. Enter the purchase order number.
    3. In the item details, go to the "Batch" tab.
    4. Expected Result 1: The Batch field should be empty and greyed out, as the system will assign the number upon posting.
    5. Post the goods receipt.
    6. A material document is created. Display the document.
    7. Expected Result 2: The system has automatically generated and assigned a new batch number to the material document item, following the internal number range configuration.
  • Pass/Fail: ____________

Test Case MM-MD-004: Validate HU-Managed Storage Location

  • Objective: To verify that standard goods movements are blocked for an HU-managed storage location and that the system correctly forces the creation of a delivery.
  • Prerequisites:
    • A storage location has been configured with the "HU Oblig." indicator set.
    • Stock of a non-HU-managed material exists in another storage location within the same plant.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Execution - Scenario A (User): Launch the "Transfer Stock - In-Plant" Fiori app (Tx MIGO, A08 -> R10).

A Practical Handbook for End Users, Key Users, and Consultants

  • Chapter 8: The Business Partner (BP) Approach
